title: Benefits to Measuring Blood Pressure in the Carotid Artery?
content: Hello, I am an electrical engineering graduate student, and I have been solicited to design a noninvasive means of measuring blood pressure at the carotid artery.  I understand there are accuracy benefits, given the proximity to the heart, but as near as I can tell the sensors will have to be at the end of a pencil-like rod to get at the artery, and achieve just the right applanation to get an accurate pressure measurement without affecting the pressure very much.  But my question, is what are the medical benefits to measuring the blood pressure at the carotid artery as opposed to the radial or brachial artery?  Can it help in earlier detection of heart disease or strokes?  Are there some papers you can direct me to?  I've found a few biomedical papers, but none articulating a clear need for such a device.    Before I throw myself into this topic, or start applying for grants, I just want to make sure I would be working on a device that would be helpful to the medical community.  Thank you very much for all your assistance, ~V.

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: Benefits to Measuring Blood Pressure in the Carotid Artery?
content: Hello,While noninvasive measures to study the carotid artery function are in the form of Doppler as non invasive methodologies certain factors are to be borne in mind while selecting the carotids to study blood pressure.Ageing and the loss of elasticity acquired during hypertension,inability to hold the blood volume,the baro- receptor sensitivity at the carotid sinus all have to be borne in mind. "Arterial alterations with aging and high blood pressure. A noninvasive study of carotid and femoral arteries"  A Benetos, S Laurent, AP Hoeks, PH Boutouyrie and ME Safar  Department of Internal Medicine, Broussais Hospital, Paris, France.  Arteriosclerosis, Thrombosis, and Vascular Biology. 1993;13:90-97 Hope this reference would clarify some points in your proposed research.Wishing you all success. Best of luck in your carrier.

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: Benefits to Measuring Blood Pressure in the Carotid Artery?
content: Hi, With the exception of perhaps a cardiac arrest scenario, in routine blood pressure monitoring in clinical settings(including critical care), "absolute" blood pressure (systolic, diastolic or mean blood pressure) readings are not to be relied upon excessively. More important than the site of recording or the actual blood pressure value, is the "change" in the value in real time - what is known as "TRENDING" , is the most useful information to be gleaned from monitoring. This holds good for most parameters in monitoring. The critical questions while monitoring are, "what is the "trend" like? Is it showing an increasing trend or is it decreasing, or remaining steady?" Absolute readings are only of secondary value.  In the cardiac arrest scenario however, while external cardiac compressions are on-going, the critical question is the blood pressure in the coronary arteries (blood supply to the heart) and the carotids(the blood supply to the brain).Your proposed technique may find an application in this context to assess the efficacy of the cardiac compressions(external cardiac massage). Good luck!

author: Dr.M.Aroon kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1340 Joined: Mon Sep 28, 2009 11:20 am Gender: Male Location: Salalah, Sultanate of Oman.
title: Re: what field deals with chemical exposure?
content: Hi, I will confine my answer only to your question regarding the adverse effects of  breathing Teflon fumes in an industrial set up.To say that this is a highly charged and controversial topic is an understatement.  Invented at DuPont's Jackson Laboratory in 1938, Teflon® (registered trademark of DuPont's)- a resin, is a fluoropolymer polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE). Ammonium salt of  the perfluorinated compound, perfluoroctanoic acid (PFOA) or C-8 is used as a surfactant in the emulsification process during manufacture of PTFE.   In its polymer form, PTFE is non-toxic and physiologically inert, but upon heating, PTFE resin generates polymer fumes. As temperatures rise, the pyrolysis of Teflon has been seen to occur. releasing pyrolytic gases, that are known to cause respiratory problems (temporary flue-like symptoms, known as "polymer fume fever" in industrial workers, with symptoms such as chest pain, dyspnea, and cough. Typically the fluoropolymer starts to degrade above 500°F. Fumes are not typically given off until the fluoropolymer starts to melt (660°F-according to Dupont).   A relatively rare but severe lung condition is acute pulmonary edema, due to inhalation of pyrolytic products of PTFE, although few cases have been reported in the literature. (Lewis C, Kerby G. An epidemic of polymer fume fever. J Am Med Assoc 1965; 191: 103–106)  It is well known that facial birth defects in the new born, an effect observed in experimental studies on the effects of PTFE on rats, occurred with the children of two out of seven female DuPont employees from the Washington Works facility from 1979–1981. DuPont did not accept any liability from the alleged ‘toxicity’ of PFOA based on their studies.  DuPont had conducted human experiments with Teflon-laced cigarettes in their employee volunteers. Nine out of ten who smoked 0.4 milligrams of Teflon developed “Polymer Fume Fever”. (Clayton JW. 1967. Fluorocarbon toxicity and biological action. In Fluorine Chemistry Reviews. 1(2),197-252).  Dupont’s studies indicate that breathing Teflon fumes at high concentrations for a full workday is equivalent to 0.4 milligrams of Teflon  per cubic meter of air over eight hours exposure.   DuPont employees are required to wear respiratory protection. As early as 1962 the company required their workers to wear respirators when working with Teflon heated at or above 400 °F in poorly ventilated areas.  (Zapp JA. 1962. Toxic and health effects of plastics and resins. Arch. Environ. Health, 4, 335. 1962).  There is also consistent evidence on associations with higher cholesterol and uric acid in people exposed to higher levels of PFOA. Whether or not these potential effects result in an increase in cardiovascular disease is unknown.   As far as your industrial setup is concerned, you need to only look into the prevailing work culture (work hours, availability of respiratory protection, level of awareness of risks involved among workers, presence or absence of surveillance mechanisms to identify toxicities early and to monitor of levels of toxic products in fumes, quality of ventilation in the work place, just to name a few). Good luck!

author: Faye Lang, RN, MSW  Nurse Posts: 468 Joined: Thu Oct 30, 2008 7:01 pm Gender: Female Location: California
title: Re: the health affects of teflon?
content: Hello, mikeytuna,  You have posed an interesting question.  When first introduced into cookware, there were many complaints that it made people sick.  There have been multiple studies and evaluations of Teflon, and there has been no evidence that it is injurious to health under normal circumstances.  Teflon is used in body piercings due to its flexibility and compatibility with the human body.  Teflon grafts are used to replace arteries in vascular diseases when a suitable vein isn't available.  In tests, Teflon is stable and non-toxic.  Fumes of many ordinary cooking oils have been measured as more toxic than the fumes from cooking with Teflon.  However, there is an exception:  when Teflon is heated above 500 degrees Fahrenheit, it begines to deterioriate.  At 662 degrees F, the fumes can be lethal to birds and may cause flu-like symptoms in humans.  Based on this information, if your work does not involve heating Teflon above 500 degrees F, there is no known health risk.  Good luck to you!

author: Dan Abshear  Medical Assistant Posts: 12 Joined: Wed Dec 31, 2008 3:34 am Gender: Male Location: Missouri, United States
title: Re: Do Drs really care about their patients?
content: Your question is an excellent one, and continues to be debated to this day.  Doctors are learned professionals.  They are experts in whatever medicine they practice.  Some are more charming than others.  If a doctor has bad bedside manner, that does not mean that the doctor is inferior as far as his skills to maintain and restore your health as a patient.  Doctors also strive to delay the progression of any chronic illness you may have- usually by utilizing pharmacological therapy, and monitoring this therapy.  Doctors do in fact have ethical obligations and legal duties as they care for you as one of their patients. They have to apply standards of care, and any treatment they offer or apply to you as a patient must be reasonable and necessary.  Yet unfortunately, many visits with a doctor are brief and to the point.  So most patents do not form what may be viewed as a relationship with their health care provider.  Most visits between the doctor and patient are simply situational acquaintances, at best.  Finally, keep in mind that doctors are very objective, and rely on their objectivity to practice medicine with quality,  Dan Abshear

author: Debbie Miller, RN  Nurse Posts: 4746 Joined: Mon Apr 16, 2007 2:41 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: Do Drs really care about their patients?
content: Hello, Just like any other profession, there are good doctors and not so good doctors.  I know for a fact there are many who care about their patients very much, who establish ongoing communication and eduction programs with them.  The doctors here are volunteers - they don't have to take time for this kind of help but they do.  This is evidence of some very caring medical professionals who want to reach out to people around the world.    It is important to have a trusting relationship with your doctor so sometimes a little shopping is in order to find that right fit.  A doctor who is perfect for one patient may not be a good choice for another one because of his/her goals for health care management.  Patients must take an active role in their care and decisions that are made by getting all the information they need to make informed decisions and to ask the right questions.  This will help them to feel comfortable.  Doctors can only help if the patient discloses full information and history, if the patient follows the recommendations, takes the medications that are prescribed properly and if the patient trusts him or her.  I don't know if this is what you were looking for but I hope it helps.  Best wishes

author: dr. janak patel  Medical Doctor Posts: 5 Joined: Sat Nov 01, 2008 5:46 am Gender: Male
title: Re: All doctors... please reply
content: The biggest disadvantage to being a doctor in the US where I practice is not having as much curing of disease and illness as one would expect. It seems medicine moves slowly for obvious safety reasons and when we donot move carefully, we pay the price or should I say our precious patients pay the price w side effects, missed diagnoses, later then desired diagnosis of disease, and then many times you may reflect and realize the huge strides we have made over the years in helping people cope w pain, suffering and complications of disease.  I also think there is a big disadvantage in that ONLY NOW at this time in history are we finally getting back to realizing that being a physician is much more  about the..... size of your heart.... then the size of your brain or wallet.  There have been similar periods in hx where being a physician was easier in that there were less distractions and greater morals, but we seem to be getting back to that type of time period now again as the superficial rewards of being a physician are fading away. Also, some of the worst times in medicine have been when patients are mistreated or assigned to a handy neat, quick diagnosis when there is much more going on clearly. Dealing w insurance companies that only want to save money by not approving tests, treatments, referrals as a knee jerk first response w/o first considering each patient as an indiviual first is very difficult if you truly care for the profession.  Dealing w hospitals that are only concerned about paying their bills and making profits . These are only some thoughts about the negatives.....  As for the positives... truly there are SO many, many precious rewards.... that  you can only feel and appreciate in your heart and inner being that all the above disadvantages stem from a healthy concern of truly caring for the ill that have placed themselves in our sacred trust to do our very best.

author: Dr.M.jagesh kamath  Medical Doctor Posts: 1303 Joined: Mon Aug 03, 2009 7:24 am Gender: Male
title: Re: 20 years old rapid hair loss
content: Hello,The causes of hairloss in your age group for women is of two types.Generalised and localised.The localised patterns are seen with an area of hairloss.Alopecia areata is an auto immune problem,and fungus infections again localised, but scaly.In your case it is generalised.The commonest cause is Telogen effluvium in which after an illness,or due to general weakness the growing hairs suddenly turn to telogen hairs.This is a normal cycle in all but the sudden change results in excess hairfall.The reason in a young female to develop this would be iron deficiency.Sure the telogen hair would turn back to anagen,ie new hair growth in time.But you may need iron and protein suppliments.Also best to get your thyroid study becaue hypothyroid states lead to hairfall.Best wishes.

author: SoTired76  Guest Posts: 10 Joined: Sat Mar 01, 2008 3:00 am Gender: Female Location: United States
title: A Patient's Perspective In the Modern World
content: “By now I am resigned to the fact that if after trying so hard, and doing my best to be patient, and if dealing with all the of these things I have been dealing with are going to be the status quo, then I will probably toss all my medicine out and get a room with a view!“  Really, I guess this has become a testament to how probably many patients feel nowadays. But, why is everyone so sick nowadays anyhow? Was it always like this before the advent of modern medicine and the commercialized world? How does one decide to continue on and pursue care as opposed to giving up, crawling into a shell, or even worse. It makes me sad to see how there are so many people suffering out there, and not enough resources, and not enough time, and not enough answers. I myself am blessed to have some answers and some resources, but I think it is normal to want to just give up on trying to get help. Why should this be normal? From what I have observed from personal experience and what I have seen in others, I am not the only one who feels this way. I can always offer a bit of advice, but I cannot hardly get the help I need. I can always be there for someone, but when I need someone to be there for me they just aren't around. This is life for the chronically ill patient of the day it seems. I have seen this over and over and over again, and there is just not enough love and help to go around. If I could spread myself thin enough to take away all the pain in the world, or to help even a few of those out there who cannot get the care or answers they need, I would do it regardless of any impact upon my own health. Those who have cared and taken time are a blessing, and since many do not have the resources readily available to them, or because their own families or practitioners are overloaded, or unavailable, then the individual is given no choice but to look on their own for help. How does one find an advocate to facilitate health care when they are too tired and weak to do this anymore for themselves? I was blessed enough to have a friend who represented me years back when I just wanted to give up completely. However, she could not get the help she needed though and eventually only was given a few years to live. I guess suffering is a big motivator for some, and concern and empathy for others. Perhaps the world would be a better place if we didn't know so much, or if we all could have the simple innocence of children. I really think it would. With all the hype, stress, over immersion of stimuli and fast paced craziness that seems to permeate through our own walls, even in our own homes in this modern world...I cannot help but wish I lived in a peaceful setting without a care but to care for those around me. Family values have changed. The Nuclear family has declined in my opinion into some morphed and mutated dream of what a real family used to be.  Many kids are raising themselves. Parents cannot afford to stay at home, and so many children grow up as latchkey kids, or in some kind of day care setting. Were mental health illnesses really so prevalent even at the beginning of the last century? Sure, there were no computers or such a news oriented high tech world in existence, but I really believe that people are suffering more than ever because of a lack of fundamental basics such as values, structure in the home, work that involved the human being as a whole and not just taxed the brain. Stressors have definitely evolved into something beyond the typical olden day worry. Now we have to try to figure out who we are more than ever. Faith is in a great decline, and money and greed have replaced the need for compassion, fidelity, and overall common sense. So mental illness seems to be on the rise. But, what can we expect in a sick world without a remedy to cure what ails it. It is hard not to be disillusioned with the plight of the world today. So, here is my view and it is only one view. It may not matter at all. If I really had the energy, I would research this and add the ideas and world views of others...especially of patients who are suffering in the modern age, particularly in the Western world. Cultural differences seem to make a big difference on how we see things. It also seems to me that things are much simpler, even if chaotic in places where such innovation and the rush for success does not exist. The Amish are a good example of a culture where family values, spirituality, and simplicity still hold true. They form together as a community to help each other out, despite the lack of health insurance or governmental help which they do not normally look to for help. They access modern health care, but they help each other. Maybe we could learn a lot from cultures such as that. Maybe if there were more family farms, and less factories, families who lived together could eat, work, learn, live, love and play together too. Sure, I enjoy modern convenience...but isn't convenience sometimes just another way to not have to actually work hard and care about each other.

author: Alexandra C, RN  Nurse Posts: 26 Joined: Fri Mar 14, 2008 3:46 pm Gender: Female Location: USA
title: Re: A Patient's Perspective In the Modern World
content: Dear SoTired76,  The tone of your post is so sad and frustrated, I just wanted to reach out to you to say that I am sorry for your suffering.  I do not know what kind of health problems you are experiencing but you indicate that you have a chronic illness and have difficulty obtaining the support you need.  I wanted to suggest to you that you seek out a support group in your area, or even online.  It sounds like you have a lot of knowledge and experience that might be helpful to others in similar situations, and likewise you may find others who can offer their understanding, knowledge and experience to you.    I agree that our health care system is at times seems overloaded and imperfect, as are many facets of our modern lives.  I also see that great progress has been made in medicine in recent years.  Globally the rate of life expectancy has increased, many diseases that once caused widespread death are now successfully treated, even eradicated, more people do have access to quality health care than ever before.  I think you're also correct that we as humans need to examine the impact that our lifestyles have on the health of our bodies, our communities, our planet as a whole, because there is a lot of room for improvement.  I also believe that change  must start within each of us.  I love the quote from Ghandi, "Be the change you want to see in the world".  You seem to have a lot of passion and great ideas about what change would do the world good.  I am certain you are not alone in that!  Good luck to you, I hope you will seek out and find ways to help yourself and others navigate towards good health.

author: Raistlin  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Fri Feb 29, 2008 4:53 pm Gender: Male
title: Question regarding workflow for referrals
content: I am not a student, but I could not find a more appropriate category in which to post my question.  I apologize for that.  My employer is building an online physician referrals system and I have been tasked with mapping the workflow involved in referring patients from one physician to another.  I find myself on this forum because I can not seem to locate an adequate description of this process.  My request is that someone would take a moment and lay out the steps that are taken by a physician's staff from the time a decision is made to refer the patient through the time the referral is scheduled and confirmed by both offices.  Thank you in advance for any assistance.
posted_time: Post  by Raistlin » Fri Feb 29, 2008 5:06 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Question regarding workflow for referrals
content: Hello Raistlin,  I'm not familiar with all the business aspects of the process but I can tell you what I know from my perspective as a physician.  Most insurance companies require a referral from a primary care physician for the insured person to be able to see a specialist.  The reason for this is to have the primary care physician (PCP) screen patients to see who truly needs to see a specialist, since specialists are more expensive to the insurance company.  The thought is that if people are allowed to go to the specialist directly more people who don't need to see the specialist will anyway.    When I, as a primary care physician, decide to refer a patient to a specialist I submit a form with the necessary information.  This is then forwarded to the insurance company and the patient can then make an appointment with the specialist.  The form serves as notice to the insurance company that I have recommended the specialist.  I hope this helps a little.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: Communication Between Doctors and Patients
content: Hey there. I'm a college student and I am doing a research paper. I'm hoping to gather some information for that assignment and possibly come back for some more...   The research is about communication between doctors and patients but nurses are welcome to join in. Well here goes....  Feel free to make your responses as long as you want. Thank you for your time and effort. Have a good time. ^.^  1. How long have you been a Doctor/Nurse?  4 years  2. On a scale of 1 to 10 (1 being the least important), how do you rate the importance of communication between you and your patients? Why?  At least a 9, it is crucial that the patient be aware of the condition and treatment plan.  A patient needs to be able to trust their doctor.  Understanding the medical plan is crucial to this.  Communication is the only way for this to occur.  3.  Why do you think communication between doctors and patients has worsened over the years?  This makes the assumption that it has.  For the most part I think you are correct.  There are some physicians that have maintained good communication but it definitely is a challenge.  Medicine has become much more business oriented.  As such, doctors are finding more and more demands on our time.  In many cases it simply is not possible to spend 30-45 minutes with each patient.  Some physicians find themselves in a position where they can only spend 10-15 minutes with each patient.  The trick is learning to communicate well during this limited time to allow the patient to feel their needs were met.  4.  How do you think communication affects the way health care is provided? (Would it help or hinder?)  This gets back to the issue of trust.  Communication enables a patient to understand what is going on and allows the patient to trust their doctor.  If this trust is not established care is often hindered.  Patients may be uncertain about taking their medications, for example, because they have not had their questions properly answered.  5.  As a doctor/nurse, in what ways do you think would help improve communication?  One of the most important issues is for physicians to make communication a priority.  Simply asking patient if they have anymore questions before leaving the room goes a long way.  I hope this helps some.  Best wishes.

author: jennifer1b  Guest Posts: 12 Joined: Fri Jun 01, 2007 9:35 am
title: Re: Communication Between Doctors and Patients
content: I am so glad you are concerned with communication, as it is the key to being a good doctor.  If you do not take the time to listen and to explain, you can and will probably miss important information.  There is so much care passed on to nurse practitioners and physicians assistants and not enough with the doctor.  I have had erroneous diagnosis from those that are not doctors.   It would seem alright to see the nurse for bloodwork or a flu shot etc. but especially as patients get older and more serious symptoms present themselves, it is important to have a doctor speak to them.  I hope you take the time to get to know your patients individually.  They all have their own personalities and histories.  You will find it helpful.  Most doctors have way too many patients to handle alone.  Is it necessary to have so many patients?  Why are waiting rooms packed and people waiting for hours along side contagious people?  Is this really the best way to treat people?  Obviously, I don't think so.  Take on a work load you can handle.  This way you won't miss vital information that can prevent a patient from a delayed diagnosis.  Good for you, doing research on this topic.

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: Re: I have been working graveyard in the er and my question
content: Hi Murphy1982,  The body will shift its usual schedule if working for extended periods of time.  So, basically your body is flipping its days and nights some.  This is why you are more tired during the day and able to stay up while working at night.  Children will also adjust their internal clocks if they are moved to a different schedule.  So, most likely, in an effort to spend more time with you your daughter started staying up later and subsequently started sleeping in later.  This can be difficult to overcome.  Some things you can try are to keep the room very dark when sleeping and bright when awake.  It will probably take you a day or two to readjust so trying to bunch your days off so that you can avoid having to flip back and forth.  This will give you the most opportunity to adjust to your schedule.  Best wishes.

author: Cutiepie  Guest Posts: 9 Joined: Sun Jun 03, 2007 5:52 pm
title: Conception & Ovulation
content: F, 26. Does every woman ovulate 14 days before her next period? How can one go about tracking your cycle and when you're likely to ovulate?  Also, if a female has a 29 day cycle on average and her last period was March 24, 2007 and ended March 28, 2007 and she had intercourse (March 29 with condom but it was ruptured partner 1), (April 1 and 3 unprotected partner2) and she learnt April 24 she was 4 weeks pregnant and conception occurred April 7 or 8, 2007, who is likely yo be the father?
posted_time: Post  by Cutiepie » Wed Jul 11, 2007 6:33 pm

author: Dr. Chan Lowe  Medical Doctor Posts: 4069 Joined: Fri Dec 08, 2006 3:35 pm
title: [no title]
content: Ovulation is generally considered to be 14 days before the first day of the next cycle though this is not necessarily always true for all women.  There are several ways for women to track ovulation including analyzing cervical mucous changes and basal body temperature changes.  As to your second question, ovulation for a 29 day cycle would generally be considered to occur on day 15 (April 7th).  Sperm can survive in the vaginal tract for about a week.  As such, it is very slightly more likely for fertilization to occur from intercourse on April 1 and April 3 but this in no way excludes the 29th.  The 29th would be generally considered about the limits of when fertilization could occur.  Really, though, there is no way to know for sure unless DNA testing is done after the baby is born or if an amniocentesis is done during the pregnancy to look at the baby's DNA.  Best wishes.

author: Dr. Russell M  Medical Doctor Posts: 650 Joined: Mon Jun 09, 2003 12:34 pm Location: USA
title: [no title]
content: Hi!  Some of the common diseases in the Indan subcontinent would be the common cold, upper respiratory tract infections like sinusitis and pharyngitis, lower respiratory tract infections like pneumonia, urinary tract infections, gastroenteritis like enteric fever (typhoid) and cholera, tuberculosis, malaria, dengue fever, Weil's disease, hepatitis, conjunctivitis, etc.  In America, I do not find much of tuberculosis, malaria, dengue, or weils. The flu is quite common. The west-nile fever is particularly common in the south central Americas.  I hope this helps.  - Bill

title: [no title]
content: When you have a miscarriage, the baby is already gone.  Perhaps you meant, if the fetus dies, does it need to be taken out.  Almost always if the fetus has died, the uterus can tell that things are not normal, and it stops producing hormones to protect it, and soon bleeding starts and forces the fetus to be pushed out.  Exactly how it happens depends on how old the fetus is.

author: Dr. Anthony Solomon  Medical Doctor Posts: 510 Joined: Mon Nov 15, 2004 6:04 pm
title: MISQUOTED COSTS
content: This is ridiculous!  There must be a procedure for complaints to the parties involved. author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Dark brown urine
content: Dear Ashley,  At any time a urinary problem is suspected, it is better to do a urine analysis.  The causes of dark-brown urine include but are not limited to:   - Concentrated urine because of dehydration and not drinking enough water and fluids. - Urinary tract infections. - Renal failure. - Liver failure. - Blood in the urine.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

title: ET
content: If someone tried to ET a person while they were awake and well. Would Lidocaine work for numbing the vocal cords, how much would you have to use? How long would it last? How would you get it there? After attempts were made would the tissue in the throat be just sore? And if you intubated the Esophagus and blood came out with it where did the blood come from? We were playing around in class and we had some problems... Thank you  Jennifer
posted_time: Post  by Jenniec » Tue Feb 24, 2004 12:59 am

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: [no title]
content: Dear Jennifer,  Lidocaine will work to numb the vocal cords and abolish the gag response which is the most feared thing during intubation for fear of aspiration if the patient vomits during intubation.  Lidocaine can administred to the throat by spraying, using a gel like formulation that one can swalow and keep in the back of the mouth for a while and by a liquid formulation that could swished and gargled.  The effect of lidocaine is short lived, if you give a patient lidocaine intravenous, its half life is between one and a half and 2 hours.  About esophageal intubation and the blood coming out, it could be from any where because most probably this is trauma secondary to intubation attempt. Could be from teeth, tongue, throat or from the esophagus itself.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Yasser Mokhtar » Tue Feb 24, 2004 2:15 pm

author: Jenniec  Guest Posts: 30 Joined: Fri Feb 06, 2004 1:51 am Location: ID  Contact:   Contact Jenniec       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Well, I am going to go to Med school next year. Right now I am in a Paramedic Program, we are just having a …learning experience, mostly for fun during our free time. No we weren’t doing this with the supervision of a Medical Doctor. We have intubated before,  and we know how to. But we have done it in an OR were everything is prefect…the patient is sedated and is limp, and the table is prefect reach. We were trying for something a little less controlled, like on the ground, mostly awake but not in an emergency situation. A few of us do not have or have very good control of the gag reflex and are able to sustain it to the point where a Laryngoscopy is possible with the Laryngoscope blade, but when going to advance the tube  (I’ll use myself as an example) I start to get a little nervous and loose control of the reflex, then gag. So we got the great idea of using Lidocaine as a local anesthetic. We just didn’t know how to administer locally to the vocal cords.   I have the feeling that the program is a little more lax on training regulations then the Med schools.  I was given a choice between having a ET tube done or a NG tube. I am just scared I would throw up with an NG tube and was promised that the ET tube would only be in for a few seconds.  Anyway, would it still be unethical to go on? We were planning on trying it tomorrow after classes, but using a spray. Thanks for your time Jennifer

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Endotracheal tube
content: Dear Jennifer,   i would encourage you all not to do that. As a paramedic most probably you will have the opportunity to intubate people in non-perfect conditions a lot and i don't think that what you are doing now is the perfect way to practice non-perfect conditions intubations because still it is a somewhat controlled situation.  Intubations have there own risks and lidocaine as well has its own severe and serious side effects. So, something might happen and then you will get into real problems.  Training programs have regulations and rules and these were put by people who have thought aobut the best way to train students and i think that if they thought that using each other for practice would make people trained better, most probably they would have gone with it and i think you have to go by the rules even though if you think they are not good enough because if you break the rules and the life of a person is endangered or lost it is going to be because the rules were broken.  i would urge you not to participate in such activities.   Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: ng tubes
content: Dear Jennifer,  ng (nasogastric) tubes go down the esophagus to the stomach through the nose (nothing to do with breathing or using a laryngoscope), could lead to minor nasal trauma though, while et (endotracheal) tube goes down the windpipe and it could cause some damage to the vocal cords in addition to other side effects.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D

content: Good Day to you all…I am sorry, I haven’t been on this site for a while and forgot about this posting until I received an e-mail this last week. As Emskyle comments are concerned, when we were playing around with this we were still in the “VERY” begging of learning about the airway system.  The professors did know that we were doing with the lidocain and airway instruments, in fact they even encouraged it.   A little background on my questions…I was in the beginning of Paramedic School, and the youngest of my class (I was very gullible).  The teacher had said that if we would attempt to stand an ET we wouldn’t have to try the NG tube.  Honestly I was disgusted by the thought of having anything go down my nose so I and a few others opted for intubation.  I was concerned about this because of all the soft tissue in the throat and the damage that could be done so I asked questions on here. NOTE: The Medical Director never did know that we did this and I am sure he would a more then a little mad if he knew the many things we did in that class. There were many things that happened in the class I took that were wrong and later I took some of those problems to higher authorities.  Since then, the Paramedic Director no longer works here, and they are getting new teachers. Another NOTE: We got the Lidocaine, Nitroglycerin and Adenosine from one of the teachers who was a nurse.   I am glad I did ask that question because it is through questions that we learn what is wrong and right. While I was learning I am glad that someone that knows more then I was there to answer my questions and be concerned about that I was doing. (Thank you to the people that responded) I don’t know if I ever posted anything about Nitro but we used to drop out BP to see the effects (very stupid!!) The teachers and Program Director were removed do to my reporting after I posted questions and received answers that it was wrong I did finish school…healthy and alive, did a paramedic internship at Grady and have moved on. There are new people in charge of the Paramedic Program I went through and a new Medical Director. Thank you for your concerns and comments. Like the Web Medic said the things that we did in that class are not reflections on the National Registry for Paramedics in the U.S.. Thank you again Jennifer

title: Biochemical changes in the body
content: a grossly obese man goes on a starvation diet consuming only 2 slices of bread and vegemite daily and water. He does this for 10 days ... what would the biochemical changes be that would occur in his body during this time and what would  the negative consequences be.
posted_time: Post  by NurseNancy » Sat Mar 26, 2005 1:58 am

author: Dr. D. Sawh  Medical Doctor Posts: 18 Joined: Sun Mar 20, 2005 7:05 am Location: GUYANA  Contact:   Contact Dr. D. Sawh       Yahoo Messenger   AOL
title: Biochemical changes in the body
content: DEAR NurseNancy, Thanks for your question. However, you didn't indicate in your profile whether u r a student nurse or any other medical professional or whether the ques. is an assignment,etc. As a result I don't know how to respond because I haven't a clue as to what exactly u are looking for. Kindly let me know if my answer below was of any help to you. I would now proceed with my answer to your question:  Biochemically, starvation implies prolonged fasting. When the obese man enters the starved state, after 3-5 days of fasting, biophysiological changes occur in his body. --- His muscles decreases its use of ketone bodies and oxidises fatty acids as its primary energy source. --- Due to decreased muscle usage, blood ketone body levels rise.--- His brain then takes up and oxidises the ketone bodies in order to derive energy. Consequently, the brain decreases its use of glucose, although glucose is still a major fuel for the brain. --- HEPATIC GLUCONEOGENESIS DECREASES. --- MUSCLE PROTEIN IS SPARED. --- Due to decreased conversion of amino-acids to glucose, LESS UREA IS PRODUCED FROM AMINO-ACIDS IN STARVATION THAN AFTER AN OVERNIGHT FAST. --- The body uses its FAT STORES AS ITS PRIMARY SOURCE OF ENERGY DURING THE 10 DAYS. --- Overall, LIPIDS ARE QUANTITATIVELY THE MOST IMPORTANT FUEL IN HIS BODY. --- The LENGTH OF TIME THAT A PERSON COULD SURVIVE ON 2 SLICES OF BREAD (source of carbohydrate), VEGEMITE & WATER DEPENDS MAINLY ON THE AMOUNT OF FAT STORED IN ADIPOSE TISSUE.--- Even after 3-4 weeks of starvation, blood glucose levels are still in the range of 65 mg/dL. IN SUMMARY, starvation causes muscle to decrease its use of ketone bodies. As a result, ketone body levels rise in the blood, and the brain uses them for energy. Consequently, the brain needs less glucose and gluconeogenesis slows, thereby, sparing muscle protein. These changes in the fuel utilisation patterns of the obese individual enabled him to survive for 10 days without SOLID FOOD. REMEMBER: TO LIVE LONGER, LESSEN THY MEALS.        (Benjamin Franklin)I SINCERELY HOPE THAT THIS IS WHAT U WERE LOOKING FOR. KINDLY LET ME KNOW A.S.A.P. YOURS TRULY,                                                                                                    D.SAWH M.D., F.R.C.P.--- [quote][/quote]

I have run cortisols, thyroids, CBCs, mono, and everything else I can think of.  I don't know what is wrong. posted_time: Post  by supertech20845 » Wed Dec 15, 2004 7:57 pm

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello: Can you tell me if there has been any changes in your life over the past six months.  For instance, have you taken on additonal work, or increased your level of responsibility? Have your eating habits changed? Have you experiences additonal stresses that you didnt have before?  Stress and tension takes a huge toll on the body and can cause extreme fatigue.  Often the things that cause stress come on gradually so that we do not realize how much stress we are under.  How do you sleep at night?  Do you experience any pain in the joints or muscles? People tend to always look for a physical disease that causes fatigue and forget that often it is the mental stresses of life that wears the body down.  Let me know about these things and perhaps we can narrow it down to one or two possibilities. Regards, Carolyn
posted_time: Post  by Carolyn Merritt, LPN » Sat Dec 18, 2004 12:58 am

title: just a question
content: im 17.5 and im five foot five my mom is 5"9 dad is 6"0 bot h my brothers 15 and 19 are 6"0 or taller i was very athletic as a kid  and was wonderin if this is as tall as i will get? any thing that i can eat specific to encourage growth?
posted_time: Post  by trees » Wed Sep 29, 2004 2:40 pm

author: Carolyn Merritt, LPN  Nurse Posts: 141 Joined: Sun Sep 19, 2004 12:36 am Location: Northern California USA
title: [no title]
content: Hello: Females usually stop growing at age 16 and males at age 18.  However, there is a wide variance in when one stops growing and it all depends on genetics.   Some males have been known to continue growing into their late 20's and in rare instances up to the age of 30. HGH or human growth hormone is responsible for our rate of growth.  Studies are being done with HGH to help children with exceptionally short stature to grow taller.  I do not know of any studies being done with those in their late teens however.  Taking a poll will only give you peoples guesses and one guess is as good as another.  It is genetics that plays the important role here.  Ask your parents about their age when they stopped growing and if your grandparents are alive I suggest asking them also.  That would be a better estimate of when you will stop growing than a poll can give you. Regards, Carolyn
posted_time: Post  by Carolyn Merritt, LPN » Sun Oct 03, 2004 10:30 am

content: Hello Luna: You didn't say whether you planned on going into medicine or whether you just wanted to learn about it. title: Re: Facial pain
content: Dear Tanya,  Is it "cephalalgia" or did it sound french like "tic doulereux"?  And regarding the intubation practice, there are models (dummies) to practice on but there is nothing like the real thing. Of course, it should never be practiced on alive healthy awake people without an indication for intubation.  One of the ways of practicing which is known is to practice on dead bodies and there are certain hospitals who have policies regarding this and they have to take the consent of the family of the deceased which allows the medical personel to practice such procedures. One of the ways to practice intubation is to go to the operating room but this is more of a controlled environment.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

title: Visiting your Doctor
content: I just joined this website.  I've been reading through the posts and I'm horrified at what some of you are posting.  If I had some of your symptoms I'd be visiting my personal Doctor for an evaluation.    Many replies are site Doctors advising posters to visit your Doctor.  Have you?  I'm curious if you found an answer to your inquiry, yet there are no futher follow-up postings.    From what I've read, this site is not a substitute for visiting your Doctor in the flesh.  All I can say is go visit your Doctor if you have any out of the ordinary symptoms.  Don't depend on the Doctors on this board.  They can only advise you based on the detail wording of your posting.  That is it.    I wish you all relief of your medical problems, so please if you think your condition warrants questioning a physician, please go see one.  thank you,  Ken

title: Re: Visiting your doctor
content: Dear Ken,  Thank you very much for using our website.  You are right.  There is no substitute for visiting one's own personal physician.   Some of the posts here on the website are patients who already saw their physicians and want a second opinion, some of them need support, i feel sometimes that some of the patients just want to get the load off their chests.   Sometimes, you will notice that some of the posters will mention that they don't have insurance or some of them like the patients in the United Kingdom don't have access to their doctors for a regular non-emergency visit except after a few months because of how the health system is constructed over their so instead of waiting and do nothing why not get an opinion from here or there.   There are few patients who give feed back on the website but i wonder about the other patients that don't give any feed back.  My explanation is that people nowadays like to talk to computers more than humans, no wonder, we are now living in the digital world era.  Once more, thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and waiting for more of your posts.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

content: I would like to poll the medical and osteopathic physicians on board here, and ask what the term "self-limited disease" means to them.  Does it mean any of the following? author: Dr. A. Rajput  Medical Doctor Posts: 74 Joined: Fri Apr 11, 2003 10:16 pm Gender: Male Location: India  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. Rajput       Yahoo Messenger
title: HENOCH-SCHOENLEIN PURPURA
content: Allergen(drugs,food,insect bite,intection,vaccination etc)##> stimulation##>elevated IgA levels -> IgA-mediated vasculitis in small vessels of involved organs -> necrotizing vasculitis##>HENOCH-SCHOENLEIN PURPURA    Mechanism of vasulitis:- *deposition of IgA-containing immune complexes with subsequent activation of complement leads to a vasculitis  *biopsy of an acute skin lesion reveals an aseptic vasculitis with fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls and perivascular cuffing of vessels
